author: DacoLordo
body:
Well I had 20k my own money. Made the right plays got up to 50. Playing with house money got too aggressive I mean I had just made 30k following the exact same strategy inversing volatility back when it was insanely stable I played SVXY only. One Trump tweet later lost all my money. Lookup XIV it got delisted but before that years of insane gains. It's not retarded when it's working, it just works until it doesn't. Many here will learn the hard way. 

People act like "I'd never be that stupid" then blow up their account and just stop posting out of embarrassment and shame. I think the warning stories are just as important. I tripled my net worth in 1hour on NVDA calls one day. It's all for naught if you don't slow down and manage risk.

author: ElephantSquad
body:
Y'all are free to do w/e but I would highly suggest you guys look for shit with high p/e, still green this year, focused on consumer spending, and have debt, or were "growth" stocks people pumped to absurdity. 

DAL and CCL and the like are now in the 2-4 p/e ratio. They have dropped 70-80%. Yes they probably will keep going down some, but you have to understand that you're now a crazy % away from each new strike price and the IV is baked in completely now. 

It may be best to move on to things like NVDA, CVNA, ROKU, MCD, CMG, LULU. Stuff that is still relatively high, has room to drop, but hasn't followed the catastrophic tank as everything else. Also high enough share price to make the distance between strikes quite small relative to something like DAL.

author: samanco
body:
Sorry to hear that man. Let me share my experience in the hope that it makes you feel better. I pasted an imgur link to my portfolio since I started options trading this year. Let me tell you that it has been a rollercoaster. Rode the highs of TSLA stock in which I used the gains to get into options trading. Rode the waves of MSFT and NVDA calls until coronavirus caused it to come crashing down. Started from scratch and became a bear, bought puts on airlines and rideshare taking my portfolio back to where it started. Until recently I started trading VXX and 3X bear ETFS in which I lost $2.3K in the span of a week. For some odd reason, it didn't phase me. It just felt like numbers on a screen. What I took away from it, is that everyday you try something new, there is a cost to it. Think of it as insurance to never make that mistake ever again. There is a lot more to lose when your portfolio ultimately grows, and it will. Think of today's losses as guarantees for tomorrow's gains

 [https://imgur.com/a/HRTIlpK](https://imgur.com/a/HRTIlpK)

author: adamo1139
body:
Oculus is just a drop in FB stock. HTC and Samsung are not trading on NYSE. Microsoft makes spec for VR glasses, but they are pretty old and low-end compared to rest of the market. HP have VR glasses, but they are based on Microsoft spec, which is shitty. Valve isn't public.

Oculus Quest uses Qualcomm Snapdragon. PC VR is like 80% NVIDIA GPU. Those are companies we can bet on. VR headsets are mostly out of stock in US and most of the western world. Ubistoft develops a game for VR, afair people who work on it were earlier developing assasins's creed.

Ignore AR headsets, Hololens 2 is not shipping even to enterprise, Magic Leap is a company full of shit, rest are Chinese prototypes without userbase.

author: KimJongUnsTrousers
body: If you're not trying to yolo it, covered calls. Premiums are so high with VIX over 30. Example: Buy 100 shares of TSLA for $75,000 (750 closing price). Sell 1 750C expiring next week to collect $4000. Do this every week, rebuy when you get called way, and you'll have doubled your money in 18 weeks by becoming the MM. Obviously, you lose if TSLA tanks. Most of the sub can't do this shit because they can't afford the shares. There are tons of high IV options. If you like semis so much, NVDA is the way to go.

author: Tairaa90
body:
Well im pretty green on the topics of stocks and business but im a PC enthusiast so there is some context here that im pretty familiar with. A year ago they had no viable offerings for a good CPU (fx was dated af and not a contender, dont tell me about the fx series as an offering) and their best GPUs were weaker and not as cost effective as nVidias. The best they had was low to medium performance options for both markets. This has been their position with respect of Intel and nVidia for a long time. Now their CPUs are king and their GPUs are competitive, even lacking a flagship as powerful as the 2080 or 2080ti. 

They have rapidly transitioned from a sustained underdog position to a real tooth and nail competitor. If we assume that this trend will continue does it not stand to reason that their share price should also continue to perform as they seize a greater market share?

This of course says nothing about server and console hardware, which im less familiar with but i hear they're doing well in those sectors as well.

author: stringfold
body:
It's not video processors where AMD's growth potential greatest -- it's in the server market, where they are currently dominating Intel in terms of performance per watt. Now, Intel is a behemoth when it comes to the server market, and they're not going to give up market share easily, but AMD is better placed to gain a substantial share of the server market from Intel now than they have ever been, and that's not hyperbole.

Video is a much tougher market position for them, with nVidia still leading substantially at the high end, and poised to release their next generation cards. AMD's limited research budget has been mostly focused on their CPU technology, as it should be, so it's going to take longer for them to catch up with nVidia, if they can at all.

author: Summebride
body:
Go back a month and keep in mind NVDA was back to $293, its old high water mark.  Nobody knew what they would report and whether it would be ok or terrible.  Many took profits, not wanting to hold the bag if the ER was tepid.

Turns out they reported a spectacular ER and incredibly positive guidance.  In any other times, it would have vaulted into the 300's with chatter about $400.  It started, but immediately corona news and Asia gloom was the talk and instead of receiving credit for the excellent ER, NVDA has been down and down.  That may not have been fair.

Fun fact: The software that was used to go from raw virus sample to full atomic-level map in 12 days was built using Nvidia CUDA and runs on Nvidia T4s and V100s.

These models help with tracking genetic drift, developing effective therapeutic treatments, and developing/improving vaccines.

Gaming saves lives.

I see increased demand for Nvidia hardware in the future.
